results.title: Ned Kelly: paintings by Sidney Nolan
results.creator_credit: Alan Harkness, Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: The story of Australia’s best known bushranger is told through the paintings of Sidney Nolan, accompanied by a ballad played on the guitar. Made with the co-operation of the Museum of Modern Art of Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alan Harkness, Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films

results.title: Industrial Britain
results.creator_credit: John Grierson, Edgar H. Anstey, Robert Joseph Flaherty and Empire Marketing Board
results.brief_description: In 1931, with Nanook, Moana and Tabu behind him, Flaherty came to London to collaborate with John Grierson’s new government-supported documentary unit at the Empire Marketing Board. By 1932, Grierson had recruited a number of young men to the unit who he coached on film projects. This documentary resulted from the collaborative efforts and contributions of such a team. The film celebrates the craftmanship of British workers and as it captures the skills of potters, machinists, glassblowers and other tradesmen engaged in their work. Photographed by Robert Flaherty with additional photgraphy by Basil Wright, Arthur Elton and John Grierson. Edited by Edgar Anstey and John Grierson. Narrated by Donald Calthrop.

results.title: Angels and acorns: Tasmanian 'colonial' stone carvings
results.creator_credit: Rodney Musch, Lindo Taylor, Norman Laird and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description: Illustrates the use of Australian sculpture in Tasmania from its earliest days to the end of the last century. Work of convict origin is shown including Ross Bridge with its notable sculptures and gargoyles. Photographer: Rodney Musch. Commentator: Bert Wicks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rodney Musch, Lindo Taylor, Norman Laird and Tasfilm Productions

results.title: Going Solo
results.brief_description:
Through life experiences such as divorce, bereavement or never meeting the right soulmate we may find ourselves fifty plus and living on our own. For some in this situation a new partner is not what they crave, just the supportive friendship of those who understand.

Based on a series of interviews conducted with members of a Catholic Women’s solo group, this 36 min amateur documentary is a first time effort for the filmmaker and although the production values are at times questionable - the heart and soul of the women interviewed shine through making this a warm, often funny and inspirational account of life for a growing number of people in our community.

holdings.name: MPEG-2 Digital File; Memory Grid Pod Full Encode

results.title: History of a day
results.brief_description:
The time lapse photography in History of a Day offers an exhilarating view of a ‘day’ unfolding before our eyes in just four minutes. The five screens of the installation surround the viewer with multiple sunrises, sunsets and lightning storms - a global dance of energy and light not available to us from our usual fixed and single perspective.

History of a Day shows us the Earth as a spinning ball of elements, driven by the laws of gravity and physics, producing, in the words of the artists, ‘a cosmic special effects theatre in continuous production, simultaneously all over the earth.’

Cinematographer Simon Carroll has been photographing time-lapse sequences for twenty years, and has amassed a large archive of material from which History of a Day was constructed. His work has been used in many films, including The Matrix (1999). Composer Martin Friedel has written music for film, theatre, opera and the concert hall, using both traditional and new media forms. He is currently a Creative Fellow at the State Library of Victoria.

(FT 30.03.05)
